title: 107_s3088
content: The Act titled "Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002" ensures that federal employees in the uniformed services or National Guard will not have their pay reduced while performing active service. The "Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002" guarantees that federal employees serving in the uniformed services or National Guard will not experience a reduction in pay during their active duty. This includes receiving an amount equal to the difference between their civilian pay and the pay and allowances for their service period. The "Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002" ensures that federal employees on active duty will receive the amount of pay and allowances for their service period that exceeds their civilian pay. This payment is applicable during pay periods when the employee is entitled to reemployment rights under chapter 43 of title 38 and does not receive basic pay. The "Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002" ensures that federal employees on active duty receive the amount of pay and allowances exceeding their civilian pay during periods entitled to reemployment rights under chapter 43 of title 38. Payment is made by the employing agency and excludes basic pay received during annual, military, or other paid leave. The "Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002" guarantees that federal employees receive the amount exceeding their civilian pay during active duty. Payment is made by the employing agency, following regulations set by the Office of Personnel Management in consultation with the Secretary of Defense. Agencies must ensure that reemployment rights apply to employees returning from service. The "Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002" mandates agencies to establish procedures ensuring reemployment rights for employees returning from service in the uniformed services. The Act defines terms like 'employee', 'Federal Government', and 'uniformed services' in alignment with section 4303 of title 38. The term 'service in the uniformed services' is defined in section 4303 of title 38 and includes duty performed by National Guard members under section 502(f) of title 32. 'Employing agency' refers to the entity of the Government where the employee has reemployment rights under chapter 43 of title 38. 'Basic pay' includes any amount payable under section 5304. The amendments made by this section ensure nonreduction in pay for those serving in the uniformed services or National Guard, effective for pay periods starting on or after September 11, 2001. Additionally, a new section is added to the Internal Revenue Code providing a Ready Reserve-National Guard employee credit. The Ready Reserve-National Guard employee credit under section 38 is 50% of the actual compensation amount for the taxable year. The actual compensation amount is the compensation paid when the employee is absent for qualified active duty. The credit is limited to 12 months and does not apply on days other than work days. The credit for Ready Reserve-National Guard employees under section 38 is 50% of actual compensation for the taxable year, limited to 12 months. No credit is allowed for days when the employee was not scheduled to work, excluding qualified active duty participation. Qualified active duty excludes training duty specified in title 10 and required drills for the National Guard. The term 'compensation' refers to remuneration for employment deductible from gross income, while a 'Ready Reserve-National Guard employee' is defined as an employee with reemployment rights and benefits under specific codes. The curr_chunk discusses the definitions of 'Ready Reserve-National Guard employee,' 'National Guard,' and 'Ready Reserve' in relation to tax deductions. Additionally, it amends the general business credit section of the tax code. The curr_chunk amends the general business credit section of the tax code to include the Ready Reserve-National Guard employee credit. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001 for the Ready Reserve-National Guard employee credit.
